titleStmt.title: Clonal Proliferation and Stochastic Pruning Orchestrate Lymph Node Vasculature Remodeling

affiliation.orgName: Institute for Research and Innovation in Biomedicine
Max Planck Institute for Molecular Biomedicine
Institute of Biochemistry and Cell Biology
State Key Laboratory of Cell Biology

analytic.title: Clonal Proliferation and Stochastic Pruning Orchestrate Lymph Node Vasculature Remodeling

biblStruct.note: Received: May 5, 2016 Revised: July 8, 2016 Accepted: August 21, 2016

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Lymph node (LN) expansion during an immune response relies on the transient remodeling of its vasculature.
Although the mechanisms driving LN endothelial cell division are beginning to be understood, a comprehensive view of LN endothelial cell dynamics at the single-cell level is lacking.
Here, we used multicolored fluorescent fate-mapping models to track the behavior of blood endothelial cells during LN expansion upon inflammation and subsequent return to homeostasis.
We found that expansion of the LN vasculature relied on the sequential assembly of endothelial cell proliferative units.

This segmented growth was sustained by the clonal proliferation of high endothelial venule (HEV) cells, which act as local progenitors to create capillaries and HEV neo-vessels at the periphery of the LN.
Return to homeostasis was accompanied by the stochastic death of pre-existing and neo-synthesized LN endothelial cells.
Thus, our fate-mapping studies unravel-at a single-cell level-the complex dynamics of vascular-tree remodeling during LN expansion and contraction.
The lymph node (LN) vasculature is composed of capillary blood endothelial cells (cBECs) and high endothelial venule (HEV) cells.

Capillaries are small blood vessels in charge of providing nutrients and oxygen to the surrounding cells, whereas HEV cells are the entryways through which blood lymphocytes access the LN parenchyma (Anderson and Anderson, 1976;Girard and Springer, 1995;Mionnet et al., 2011).
During an immune response, LN expansion relies on the transient remodeling of its vasculature (Anderson et al., 1975;Chyou et al., 2008;Kumar et al., 2012;Webster et al., 2006).
The remodeling of the LN vasculature is controlled by multiple cell types and is divided into sequential, overlapping phases.

In the first few days, the blood vasculature undergoes a rapid proliferative growth that is initially dependent on IL-1b-secreting CD11c + cells and their ability to stimulate vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) by the fibroblastic reticular cell network located in the T cell zone of the LNs.
This initiation phase is followed by a T-celland B-cell-dependent expansion phase and ends with the re-establishment of quiescence and stabilization (Benahmed et al., 2014;Webster et al., 2006).

Although we have begun to understand how LN endothelial cells (ECs) integrate multiple signals to expand during the immune response, we still have little knowledge of how individual ECs collectively behave to sustain the expansion of the LN vasculature.

Blood vessel development is a regulated process involving the proliferation, migration, and remodeling of ECs from adjacent pre-existing blood vessels (angiogenesis) or following differentiation of endothelial progenitor cells (EPCs) from mesodermal precursors (vasculogenesis) (Rafii and Lyden, 2003).
EPCs were originally thought to be present only during embryonic development.
However, evidence accumulated in the past several years suggests that they can persist in the bone marrow (BM) and/or in circulation into adult life.

In addition, resident vascular stem cells also populate the pre-existing blood vessels of various non-immunological organs (Asahara et al., 1997;Hill et al., 2003;Naito et al., 2012;Tepper et al., 2005).
Whether LN vascular remodeling relies on the recruitment of circulating EPCs, the proliferation of LN-resident EPCs, or the division of all LN endothelial subsets is unclear.
The cellular dynamics that orchestrate remodeling of the LN vasculature remain elusive for several reasons.
First, we currently lack tools to map the dynamic fate of ECs at the single-cell level in vivo.
The dynamic behavior of lymphocytes is routinely analyzed by intravital two-photon microscopy (Cahalan et al., 2002;Miller et al., 2002).

Events such as leukocyte migration or interactions between dendritic cells (DCs) and T cells typically last a few hours and can be imaged with this technology (Mempel et al., 2004;Miller et al., 2002).
In contrast, the remodeling of the LN vasculature is a long-lasting phenomenon that spans days or weeks and is therefore not accessible by intravital imaging.
Second, studies using conventional confocal and fluorescence imaging achieve a cellular resolution when imaging 8-to 30-mm-thick tissue sections.
However, these samples are too thin to allow visualization of the complex 3D vascular network and a full appreciation of its organization.

Macroscopic imaging techniques such as optical projection tomography (OPT) allow the reconstruction of the vascular tree but lack the resolution to image its individual cellular components (Kumar et al., 2012).
Understanding the remodeling of the LN vascular network will require a combination of macroscopic and retrospective single-cell imaging techniques.
In lineage tracing, a single cell is marked in such a way that the marker is transmitted to the cell's progeny, resulting in a set of labeled clones (Kretzschmar and Watt, 2012).
Lineage tracing provides information about the number of progeny of the founder cell, their location, and their differentiation status.

The recent development of multicolored fate-mapping systems based on the Brainbow approach has created new tools for studing cell dynamics in situ (Ghigo et al., 2013;Livet et al., 2007;Snippert et al., 2010).
The use of multiple colors within one cell population allows for a shift in the types of questions that can be asked by standard reporter models.
Labeling strategies often use a given promoter to drive one-color expression for all members of that particular cell type, which distinguishes that cell type from others.
Although this strategy is ideal for investigating the behavior of cells at the population level, it cannot investigate the behavior of single cells belonging to that population.
The Brainbow approach distinguishes among like cells and is ideal for following individual cells over time and space.

Given that Brainbow colors are inheritable, an initial pool of progenitor cells that is labeled with specific colors produces labeled progenies that reflect their cellular lineage, hence allowing the establishment of parentage relationship between different cell types (Hampel et al., 2011;Jarjour et al., 2014;Pan et al., 2013;Snippert et al., 2010).
Here, we used different multicolored fate-mapping mouse models to track the individual behavior of LN ECs during the inflammatory response and its resolution.
We observed that during an immune response, ECs clonally proliferated and sequentially assembled into contiguous segments along the vascular tree of the LNs.
HEV cells acted as local EPCs to create capillaries and HEV neo-vessels at the periphery of the LNs.
When the immune response was over, the return to homeostasis was accompanied by the stochastic death of pre-existing and neo-synthesized LN ECs.

div.head: Imaging the Vasculature Network of the Adult Mouse LN at Single-Cell Resolution

p.s: The initial formation of the vascular network of the mouse (vasculogenesis) relies on the massive expansion of ECs (Patan, 2004).

Genetic Brainbow labeling of the endothelium with a straight endothelial-Cre reporter would occur during development and hence result in the formation of large monocolored sections of blood vessels in adult mice, preventing us from assessing the subsequent behavior of LN ECs during an immune response.

To bypass this developmental phase and assess the remodelling of the LN vasculature during inflammation, we utilized the Cdh5-Cre ERT2 mouse, in which the tamoxifen-inducible Crerecombinase (Cre-ERT2) is placed under the regulation of the vascular endothelial cadherin promoter (Cdh5) (So ¨rensen et al., 2009).
We crossed Cdh5-Cre ERT2 mice with Rosa26-RFP mice (referred to as Cdh5 RFP ) to conditionally label adult LN ECs.

Tamoxifen treatment of adult Cdh5 RFP mice selectively labeled CD45 À CD31 + LN ECs, including peripheral node addressin + (PNAd + )gp38 À HEV cells, PNAd À gp38 À cBECs, and CD45 À gp38 + CD31 + lymphatic ECs, but did not mark other stromal or hematopoietic cell populations.
No labeling was observed in the LN ECs of non-treated animals (Figure 1A).
Conventional tissue sections are too thin to display the complexity of vasculature trees, and macroscopic imaging techniques such as OPT fail to achieve cellular resolution (Figure 1B, left panel).

Recently, several procedures have been developed for obtaining optically transparent tissue samples for imaging (Chung et al., 2013;Dodt et al., 2007;Ert€ urk et al., 2012;Hama et al., 2011;Susaki et al., 2014).
We developed a similar protocol to reconstruct large sections of the LN vascular tree with high resolution while maintaining the endogenous fluorescence of the cells.
LNs harvested from tamoxifen-treated Cdh5 RFP adult mice were sliced in 200-mm-thick sections with a vibratome and stained for CD146 (pan-endothelial marker) and PNAd expression.
Labeled vibratome slices were optically clarified and imaged with a confocal microscope.
We tiled high-resolution 3D images acquired in small fields of view to reconstruct the LN vascular network.
As shown in Figures 1B (right panel) and 1C and Movie S1, this protocol unraveled the complex arborization of the LN vasculature at high resolution.

Remodeling the LN Vasculature Relies on the Sequential Assembly of EPUs along the Expanding Vascular Tree Having established an experimental protocol for imaging the LN vascular tree at the cellular level, we designed a multicolored fluorescent model to track the behavior of individual LN ECs in inflamed LNs.
We crossed Cdh5-Cre ERT2 mice with Ubow homozygous mice (referred as Cdh5 Ubow ), in which the Brainbow 1.0 L construct is under the control of the ubiquitin C (Ubc) promoter (Ghigo et al., 2013).
In these mice, all cells express TdTomato.
After Cre recombination, cyan fluorescent protein (CFP) or yellow fluorescent protein (YFP) is exclusively expressed by each copy of the Brainbow construct (Livet et al., 2007).

Upon (legend continued on next page) tamoxifen treatment of adult Cdh5 Ubow mice, quiescent ECs undergo Cre-mediated recombination of the two Brainbow constructs and stochastically acquire various colors (Figures 2A and 2B).
During an immune response, labeled ECs should divide and transmit their colors to their progeny, highlighting the cellular dynamics of the LN vascular expansion.

We reasoned that if all LN ECs equally divide several times to accompany LN enlargement, numerous but small colored segments of blood vessels should appear throughout the vascular tree (Figure 2B, model 1).
Alternatively, if only some EPCs massively proliferate to generate additional ECs, the expanded vasculature should harbor larger monocolored segments of blood endothelium (Figure 2B,model 2).

Finally, because expansion of the LN vasculature also relies on sprouting angiogenesis (Kumar et al., 2012), this approach should unravel the cellular dynamics that orchestrate the construction of neo-vessels (Figure 2B, model 3).
To this end, adult Cdh5 Ubow mice were treated with tamoxifen and injected 1 week later with complete Freund adjuvant (CFA) in their ear and rear footpads.
3 weeks later, mice were injected i.v. with labeled LN cells and euthanized 10 min later, allowing injected lymphocytes to adhere to and thus locate functional HEV cells in vivo.
Confocal analysis of clarified control LNs indicated a random distribution of labeled ECs (Figure 2C, left panel).

In contrast, the expanded vascular tree of the inflamed LNs contained numerous and contiguous monocolored endothelial HEV segments, corresponding to the massive expansion of a restricted number of ECs (Figure 2C, right panel; Figure S1; and Movies S2, S3, and S4).

To formally prove that the appearance of HEV cell clusters was not arbitrary in inflamed LNs, we utilized ClusterQuant, a software package we previously developed to determine the randomness of cluster formation in 2D confocal datasets.
In ClusterQuant, the differentially colored cell populations (CFP + , YFP + , and CFP + YFP + ) are manually labeled within microscopic images (Figure 2D).

Subsequently, automatic computation of the corresponding Voronoi diagrams is combined with Monte Carlo simulations to obtain a quantitative statistical measure of the spatial distribution pattern of the ECs (i.e., significant cluster formation versus random cell distribution; see Experimental Procedures and Ghigo et al., 2013, for technical details).
The results showed with high significance that all colored HEV cell populations formed clusters in inflamed but not control LNs (Figure 2E).
These data indicate that LN vascular expansion is a segmented process that relies on the sequential assembly of EPUs each composed of an initiating EC and its clonal progeny.

div.head: Remodeling the LN Vasculature Depends on Local ECs

p.s: Our data indicate that some ECs extensively proliferate upon inflammation to construct the segmented vascular tree observed in the inflamed LNs of Cdh5 Ubow mice.
We then sought to identify these proliferating ECs.

As observed in multiple organs, circulating EPCs originating from the BM might home to and proliferate in the draining LNs (Asahara et al., 1997;Hill et al., 2003;Naito et al., 2012;Tepper et al., 2005).
Alternatively, expansion of the LN vascular tree might exclusively rely on LN-resident ECs.
We set up BM chimeric mice to assess the contribution of BM-derived EPCs.
To this aim, ubiquitin TdTomato (Ubc TOM ) mice were irradiated and replenished with BM cells isolated from ubiquitin GFP (Ubc GFP ) mice.
Reconstituted chimeric mice were injected with CFA, and their inflamed draining LNs were analyzed 3 weeks later by flow cytometry.
Although GFP + donor-derived cells efficiently reconstituted the hematopoietic system of the host, they did not contribute to the vascular tree of inflamed LNs (Figure 3A).

Because it remains possible that host radio-resistant BM EPCs prevent the engraftment of donor BM EPCs in chimeric mice, we assessed the contribution of circulating EPCs in parabiotic mice sharing a common blood-circulation system (Waskow, 2010).
Wild-type (WT) and Ubc TOM mice were surgically joined.
3 months later, the WT partner was injected with CFA, and the contribution of the Ubc TOM partner to the expanding vasculature of the WT partner was analyzed 3 weeks later by flow cytometry.
As shown in Figure 3B, Tomato + cells successfully colonized the WT partner and contributed to half of its T and B cell populations.
On the contrary, Tomato + cells failed to engraft in the inflamed LN vascular tree of the WT host, demonstrating that LN vascular expansion exclusively relies on local ECs.

div.head: HEV Cells Act as Endothelial Progenitors

p.s: Expansion of the LN vascular tree relies on the expansion of blood vessels and the arborization of neo-vessels from pre-existing ones (sprouting angiogenesis) (Kumar et al., 2012).
We used Cdh5 Ubow mice to track the cellular dynamics that accompany sprouting angiogenesis during LN vascular remodeling.
HEV cells are post-capillary venules connected to arterioles, from which they receive the blood leukocyte input.
Monocolored HEV sprouts observed in the inflamed LNs of Cdh5 Ubow mice must therefore connect to the capillary network to fulfill their function.

To decipher the parental relationship that might link cBECs and HEV cells, we first identified blood capillaries harboring a single color (hence resulting from the proliferation of individual ECs) and investigated the color of the HEV segments to which they were each attached.

In 80% (81 of 102) of cases, we determined that monocolored capillaries were connected to an HEV segment bearing a similar color, suggesting a parental relationship between cBECs and HEV cells (Figures 4A and 4B).

In the absence of animal models to differentially map the fate of cBECs and HEV cells in vivo, we further investigated the ability of purified cBECs and HEV cells to form endothelial vessels upon intra-LN injection.

RFP-expressing cBECs and HEV cells were isolated from tamoxifen-treated Cdh5 RFP mice and injected directly into the left (cBECs) or right (HEV cells) inguinal LNs of WT mice that had been immunized with CFA 3 days earlier (Figure 4C).
The ability of the grafted RFP + cBECs or HEV cells to generate RFP + capillaries in the host LNs was assessed 3 weeks later by confocal imaging.
As shown in Figures 4D and 4E, cBECs were able to generate a few capillaries but were unable to give rise to HEV cells.
On the contrary, HEV cells were able to rebuild HEV segments and capillaries.
These segments were embedded in the pre-existing vascular network and were functional, as revealed by their ability to support lymphocyte adherence.
Similar results were obtained when cBECs and HEV cells were sorted by flow cytometry (purity > 98%) in an approach that did not require cBEC antibody labeling (Figure S2).
Perivascular cells and/or pericytes ensheath and tightly interact with ECs.
These mesenchymal cells have been suggested to act as progenitors of other stromal cells (Krautler et al., 2012).

To exclude the possibility that a few pericytes were co-transferred with HEV cells and generated new blood vessels, we took advantage of Wnt1-Cre Ubow mice, a transgenic mouse widely used for mapping the fate of neural crest cells, a transient, multi-potent, migratory cell population that gives rise to mesenchymal structures only in the head and neck (Jiang et al., 2000).
In Wnt1-Cre Ubow mice, the mesenchymal stromal cells in the cervical and mandibular LNs express CFP, YFP, or a combination of both fluorescent proteins (Jarjour et al., 2014).
We injected CFA in the ears of Wnt1-Cre Ubow mice and analyzed their inflamed draining LNs 3 weeks later.

As shown in Figure S3, fibroblastic reticular cells and Itga7 + pericytes (Malhotra et al., 2012), but not ECs, were labeled in these LNs, hence demonstrating that ECs cannot originate from mesenchymal precursors and/or pericytes.
Finally, we determined that HEV cells were more efficient than cBECs in effluxing lipophilic fluorescent dyes in vitro, a property shared by tissue-resident EPCs (Figure S4).
We concluded that HEV cells can act as progenitors of all LN blood ECs, despite their highly specialized primary function.

Return to LN Quiescence Relies on the Stochastic Death of Preexisting and Neo-synthesized ECs LNs are highly plastic organs that constantly adapt their size to the immunological status of the organs they monitor.
Upon infection, LNs massively enlarge (up to 10-fold) in a few days and eventually return to their initial size when the immune response is over.
Although the enlargment of the LN is sustained by the proliferation of its ECs, we critically lack information about the reorganization of the vascular tree upon LN return to homeostasis.
During the adult ovarian cycle, growth and regression of the corpus luteum are accompanied by sprouting and regression of blood vessels.

Vessel constriction and occlusion are followed by rounding and detachment of single ECs and EC sheets from the extracellular matrix and subsequent shedding into the circulation (Goede et al., 1998;Modlich et al., 1996).
We anticipated that the return of LNs to quiescence also relies on vessel regression.

This process could stochastically affect all ECs or preferentially target the neo-vessels generated during the expansion phase, hence allowing the maintenance of the pre-existing vascular network in LNs that have returned to quiescence.

We tracked the behavior of neo-synthesized ECs by using Apelin Cre ERT2 mice, in which hypoxic and VEGF-responding ECs and their progeny, but not quiescent vasculature, can be genetically labeled upon tamoxifen injection (Liu et al., 2015).

Apelin Cre ERT2 mice were crossed with Rosa26-TdTomato mice (referred to as Apln TOM ) and injected subcutaneously with vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV) to trigger a transient expansion of the draining LNs.
Tamoxifen was injected 1 day later intraperitoneally (i.p.) to permanently label neo-synthesized ECs and their progeny (Figure 5A).
Draining LNs were analyzed at the peak of the response (day 7) and when they had returned to homeostasis (day 60) (Figure 5B).

As anticipated from the increased size of the LNs, VSV infection induced a transient proliferation of HEV cells and a subsequent decrease in their numbers during the return to LN quiescence (Figure 5C).
We then analyzed the percentage of neo-synthesized Tomato + HEV cells at the peak of the response and in post-inflammatory LNs that had returned to homeostasis.
We reasonned that if neo-synthesized Tomato + HEV cells were prone to die upon LN contraction, the percentage of Tomato + HEV cells should decrease between days 7 and 60.

In contrast, if neo-synthesized Tomato + and non-fluorescent quiescent HEV cells were equally eliminated in the process, the percentage of Tomato + HEV cells should be maintained between days 7 and 60.
As shown in Figure 5D, the percentage of Tomato + HEV cells increased at day 7 and remained constant in LNs that had returned to homeostasis at day 60.

Confocal imaging of LN slices revealed that Tomato + neo-vessels generated at the peak of the response (day 7) were mainly located in the LN paracortex, in the B cell follicles, and at the T-B border, precisely where HEV cells are located (Figure 5E; Baje ´noff et al., 2003;Gretz et al., 1997).
These vessels remained present in quiescent LNs that had returned to homeostasis, confirming our flow cytometric analysis (Figure 5E).

Our results suggest that during an immune response, elongation of existing vessels and sprouting angiogenesis extend the vascular network at the periphery of the LN and that return to LN quiescence involves the stochastic elimination of superfluous ECs to readjust the decreasing metabolic needs of the LN.
cBECs and HEV cells assemble to form the dense and complex three-dimensional vasculature of the LN.
Upon immunization, this vascular network transiently expands and remodels to support the development of the immune response.
The present study investigated the cellular dynamics that orchestrate this remodelling.
Our results have revealed that LN vasculature expansion relies on the sequential assembly of EC proliferative units (EPUs).
This segmented growth is sustained by the clonal proliferation of HEV cells, which can act as local progenitors to create capillaries and HEV neo-vessels at the periphery of the LN.
Return to homeostasis is accompanied by the stochastic death of pre-existing and neo-synthesized LN ECs.
Over the past decade, it has become clear that individual ECs adopt specialized phenotypes and functions to coordinate behavior in what might best be described as teamwork (De Smet et al., 2009).
Tip cells are the leading cells of the sprouts.
With their continuously searching filopodia, they sense and respond to guidance cues in their microenvironment.
Stalk cells trail behind the tip cell and elongate the stalk of the sprout; they proliferate, form junctions, lay down extracellular matrix, and form a lumen.
Phalanx cells are the most quiescent ECs and line vessels once the new vessel branches have been consolidated.
The whole process is tightly regulated by VEGF factor A and notch ligand delta-like 4 (DLL4) (Napp et al., 2012;Suchting et al., 2007).

The segmented growth of the vascular network observed in our multicolored fate-mapping system indicates that multiple clones of stalk and phallanx cells were sequentially assembled during sprouting angiogenesis.
Given our observation that the expansion of the LN vasculature exclusively relied on local ECs, we can envision two non-mutually exclusive scenarios.
In the first, a stalk cell is selected to proliferate, clonally divides, and simultaneously represses the division of the surrounding stalk cells.
Divided stalk cells transform into quiescent phalanx cells as the sprout grows, generating a monocolor segment of the vascular tree.

The multicolored, segmented growth of the vascular network implies that the proliferation of stalk cells is not infinite and rather suggests that stalk cells behave as transit amplifying cells endowed with a limited number of divisions, similarly to what has been observed during the homeostatic renewal of the skin epidermis and the epithelium of the gut (Hsu et al., 2014).
Alternatively, it has been shown that tip and stalk cells dynamically compete and frequently exchange their position and role during sprouting angiogenesis (Jakobsson et al., 2010).
Therefore, proliferating stalk cells could replace non-proliferating tip cells at the lead of the sprout.
Tip cells could then acquire the proliferative ability of stalk cells and create a new segment of the sprout.
We observed that HEV cells were much more efficient than cBECs at generating HEV segments and blood capillaries during LN expansion.
The poor ability of cBECs to generate new blood vessels might reflect their physiological inability to participate in the expansion of the LN vasculature.
However, we cannot rule out the possibility that this behavior was dictated by our experimental setup.
Even if cBECs were as viable as HEV cells at the end of the isolation process, they could have been more affected by the isolation steps and less prone to divide in grafted LNs.
The motility of the grafted cBECs could also have been compromised, hence preventing them from joining the existing vascular network and participating in its expansion.
Therefore, our results do not allow us to conclude on the participation of cBECs to the remodelling of the LN vascular tree.

However, the potentiality of HEV cells to give rise to new HEV cells and capillaries in the same assay indicates that HEV cells can act as a reservoir of EPCs ready to proliferate and sprout to remodel the LN vascular network during an immune response.

HEV cells are perceived as highly differentiated cells with a unique function in regulating leukocyte trafficking throughout the LNs (Girard and Springer, 1995;Lee et al., 2014;Mionnet et al., 2011;Schoefl, 1972).

However, several studies suggest that adult HEV cells exhibit a remarkable plasticity: HEV cells freshly isolated from lymphoid organs rapidly lose their specialized characteristics upon afferent lymphatic occlusion or when confronted with new microenvironments (Lacorre et al., 2004;Mebius et al., 1991).
Upon oxazolone immunization, HEV cells transiently revert to an immature phenotype in vivo (Liao and Ruddle, 2006).
These observations indicate that HEV cells continuously adapt their phenotype and function to the LN environmental cues.

Anderson et al. described that upon skin allograft, draining LNs displayed an increased length and arborization of HEV cells as a result of the focal proliferation of ECs in transition zones from high to low endothelium (Anderson et al., 1975).

Lymphocytes enter the LN preferentially through HEV cells within the paracortical area, a region that contains order III-V venules that support L-selectin-dependent adhesion more efficiently than order I or II venules in the medulla and hilus (von Andrian, 1996;Warnock et al., 1998).

Order III-V venules are located at the T-B border and thus ideally located to rapidly expand the capillary network of the adjacent T and B cell areas while drastically increasing the number of entry points for blood-circulating leucocytes, an observation that we experimentally confirmed with the Apln Cre ERT2 mouse.
HEV cells are post-capillary venules connected to arterial capillaries, from which they receive the blood cellular input.
As a result, HEV sprouts need to connect to the capillary network in order to be functional.
Using a zebrafish fin-regeneration model, Xu et al. recently demonstrated that arteries are formed by veinderived ECs (Xu et al., 2014).

Having demonstrated that transplanted venous HEV cells give rise to arterial cBECs and that monocolored capillaries tend to be connected to HEV segments bearing a similar color, we propose a model in which HEV sprouts create cBECs to connect the existing arterial capillary system.
All together, previously published results and our current results support a model in which HEV cells actively proliferate and sprout to extend the LN vascular network upon immunization.

Expansion of the blood vasculature is initially dependent on CD11c + cells and their ability to stimulate VEGF by the fibroblastic reticular cell network located in the T cell zone of the LNs (Benahmed et al., 2014;Webster et al., 2006).
In addition, a direct interaction between DC-derived lymphotoxin and LTbR expressed on HEV cells is critical to maintain their phenotype and function (Moussion and Girard, 2011).

Because DCs massively migrate to the draining LNs and settle nearby HEV cells during an immune response, they could be ideally positioned to regulate HEV cell homeostasis and instruct them to rapidly proliferate (Baje ´noff et al., 2003;Fo ¨rster et al., 2012).
The diffusion of oxygen through tissues is limited to 100-200 mm; therefore, a highly developed vascular system has evolved to ensure that all cells are within this distance of a supply of oxygen.
During an infection, draining LNs rapidly enlarge in response to the influx of leukocytes.
In order to meet these metabolic needs, the LN vascular tree rapidly expands and arborizes to supply every cell with oxygen and nutrients.
At the end of an immune response, the LN returns to its initial size and must therefore prune the superfluous vessels.

Vessel regression is an understudied yet emerging field of research that has received little attention by immunologists, and the initial triggers selecting particular branches for vessel regression are largely unknown.

Our data indicate that pre-existing vessels and neo-vessels are pruned at the same pace, suggesting that return to LN quiescence does not depend on the age of the vessel but rather depends on parameters that remain to be identified.
Non-perfused vessels are predisposed to vascular pruning, and changes in blood flow act as regulators of vessel regression (Ando and Yamamoto, 2009).
It was proposed more than a century ago that the vessels with the highest blood flow enlarge and those carrying the least blood flow regress (Thoma, 1893).
Several follow-up studies confirmed the importance of hemodynamic forces for vascular remodeling in zebrafish, chickens, and mice (Chen et al., 2012;le Noble et al., 2004;Lucitti et al., 2007).
LNs are fed by a single arteriole that has been shown to expand to accommodate an increase in blood flow during an immune response (Soderberg et al., 2005).

At the end of the response, when the LN (and its central arteriole) return to quiescence, we anticipate that each blood vessel will endure a drastic loss of hemodynamic forces given that a smaller amount of blood will travel throughout the expanded vascular network.
In such a model, blood vessels would be pruned to eliminate the excessive branches that are no longer necessary to supply oxygen.
It remains to be determined whether vessel pruning is stimulated by active signaling pathways or whether it results from the withdrawal of survival factors, or a combination of both.

In sum, our data suggest that a stepwise remodeling of the LN vascular network is orchestrated by the clonal proliferation of HEV cells and the stochastic pruning of superfluous vessels during the return to LN quiescence.
The Ubow mouse was generated as described previously (Ghigo et al., 2013).
Ubc GFP mice and Rosa TdTomato mice were purchased from the Jackson Laboratory.
Cdh5 Cre ERT2 mice were provided by Ralf H. Adams (So ¨rensen et al., 2009).
Apln Cre ERT2 mice were provided by Bin Zhou (Liu et al., 2015).
Wnt1-Cre mice were kindly provided by M. Coles.
C57BL/6N (WT) mice were purchased from Charles River Laboratories.
All mice were maintained in individually ventilated cages and were used at the age of 6-9 weeks.
Experiments were performed in accordance with national and regional guidelines under permission number 5-01022012 after review and approval by the animal ethics committee of Marseille (France).
Mice were either treated for 1 week with a diet of 400 ppm tamoxifen citrate (Harlan) or gavaged with 3 mg of tamoxifen and corn oil (Sigma Aldrich) for Apln TOM experiments.
Parabiosis 10-week-old WT and Ubc TOM mice were surgically attached as described in Waskow (2010).
Parabionts were analyzed 12 weeks later.
Mice were g-irradiated (twice with 500 rads) from an X-ray source and were reconstituted with at least five million BM cells.
Chimeras were used 8 weeks after reconstitution.

The following antibodies were purchased from BD Biosciences Pharmingen: RA3-6B2 specific to B220, 17A2 specific to the CD3 complex, MECA-79 specific to PNAd, 8.1.1 specific to gp38 (Podoplanin), 390 specific to CD31, 30-F-11 specific to CD45, and ME-9F1 specific to CD146.
These antibodies were visualized by direct coupling to allophycocyanin or Alexa Fluor 488, 568, or 647 or with the use of secondary antibodies coupled to Alexa Fluor 488, 568, or 647.

Skin-draining LNs from individual mice were dissected and then incubated for 50-60 min at 37 C in RPMI medium containing 0.1 mg/mL Dnase I (Sigma), 400 U/mL collagenase I (Invitrogen), and 1 mg/mL dispase (Invitrogen).
Cells were collected every 15-20 min, after which the digestion medium was replaced with fresh digestion medium.
Single-cell suspensions were stained in flow cytometry buffer and stained with the LIVE/DEAD stain kit (ThermoFisher).

cBECs were identified as CD45 À CD31 + gp38 À PNAd À cells, HEV cells were identified as CD45 À CD31 + gp38 À PNAd + cells, and lymphatic endothelial cells (LECs) were identified as CD45 À CD31 + gp38 + PNAd À cells.
LNs were fixed in Antigen Fix (Microm Microtech) for 5 hr, washed in phosphate buffer, sliced with a vibratome (Leica VT1200), and stained for the indicated markers.
200-mm-thick slices were clarified with Rapiclear 1.47 (SunJin Lab) for 1 day.
Immunofluorescence confocal microscopy was performed with a Zeiss LSM 880 confocal microscope.
Separate images were collected for each fluorochrome and overlaid to create a multicolored image.
Final image processing was performed with Imaris software (Bitplane) and Adobe Photoshop.
Adoptive Transfers LN cells were purified from the LNs of WT mice and stained with 5 mM DDAO-SE (Invitrogen) at 37 C for 15 min.
20 million cells were transferred into host mice by intravenous injection.
Single-cell suspensions from pooled skin-draining LNs underwent enrichment for CD45 À stromal cells with the use of CD45 microbeads (Miltenyi biotec).
The CD45 À stromal fraction was further incubated with a biotinylated-PNAdspecific antibody and anti-biotin microbeads.
The PNAd + fraction contained >90% of CD45 À CD31 + gp38 À PNAd + HEV cells.
The CD45 À PNAd À fraction was further incubated with a biotinylated-gp38-specific antibody and antibiotin microbeads for the removal of gp38 + cells (LECs and FRCs).
The CD45 À PNAd À gp38 À fraction was enriched with CD31 + cells with the use of CD31 microbeads.
The fraction contained >95% of CD45 À gp38 À PNAd À CD31 + cBECs.
Donor cBECs and HEV cells were magnetically enriched from the skin-draining LNs of Cdh5 RFP mice treated with tamoxifen 1 week previously (see above for EC enrichment).

WT mice were immunized at the base of their tail with an emulsion of CFA. 3 days later, inguinal LNs were exposed, and 1 mL of matrigel (Becton) containing 5 3 10 3 to 5 3 10 4 cBECs was injected into the left inguinal LNs with a 2.5 mL Hamilton syringe mounted with a 33G needle.
The same number of HEV cells was injected in the right inguinal LN of the same mouse.

Quantification and statistical analysis of the spatial distribution of HEV cells consisted of three modules combined in the ClusterQuant software, which we developed with the CognitionMaster image-analysis platform (http:// sourceforge.net/projects/cognitionmaster/)
on the basis of C#/.NET.
Computations were performed on standard hardware running Microsoft Windows 7 64 bit.

In the first module, we defined the different HEV cell classes with the Region-of-Interest plugin (ROImanager) of ClusterQuant/CognitionMaster and labeled the respective cells manually to obtain the cell-center coordinates for the subsequent processing step.
The second module computed the twodimensional Voronoi mesh on the basis of the manually labeled cell centers.

The resulting tesselation established the neighborhood relationships between the cells, which we used to evaluate the number of cells (of the same type) assembled in clusters and the respective cluster sizes.

Although this step provides a robust and objective means of quantifying cell clusters, it does not yet allow for an assessment of the (non-)randomness of the spatial cell distribution and cluster formation.
To achieve this, in the final step, we used Monte Carlo simulations based on the original experimental image data.
In the 10,000 simulation runs we performed for each experimental dataset, we randomly reshuffled the cell-type labels defined in the original data by using the original cell positions.
For each simulation run, we computed the spatial statistics (Voronoi mesh, neighborhood, and cell-cluster features) as we did for the experimentally obtained images.
After all simulation runs were completed, we compared the results of the spatial statistics between the real and simulated data.

The ratio between the number of simulations in which the average cluster size was larger than in the real data and the total number of Monte Carlo simulations (here, 10,000) yielded p values indicating the probability that an experimentally observed cluster formation might as well have been achieved by random cell distribution.
Supplemental Information includes four figures and four movies and can be found with this article online at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.immuni.2016.
Figure 1.
Three-Dimensional Imaging of the LN Vascular Tree at High Resolution
(A) Flow cytometric analysis of LN CD45-depleted stromal cells and CD45 + hematopoietic cells harvested from Cdh5 RFP mice treated or not treated with tamoxifen for 1 week.
Values indicate the percentage of RFP + cells within the indicated cell populations (n = 4 mice).
Abbreviations are as follows: HEV, high endothelial venule cell (pink); cBEC, capillary blood endothelial cell (blue); and LEC, lymphatic endothelial cell (orange).

(B) LNs from tamoxifen-treated Cdh5 RFP mice were sectioned either with a cryostat (20 mm thickness, left panel) or with a vibratome (200 mm thickness, right panel), stained for CD146 (white) and PNAd (green) expression, and clarified.
Confocal images acquired in small fields of view were tiled to reconstruct a 3D portion of the LN vascular network (n = 4 mice).
Scale bar represents 200 mm.

See also Movie S1. (C) For localization of functional PNAd + HEVs in situ, total LN cells were labeled with the fluorescent dye DDAO-SE and injected i.v. 10 min before the harvest of the LN (n = 3 mice).
Scale bar represents 100 mm.
Figure 1.
Continued
Figure 2. Expansion of the LN Vasculature Relies on the Sequential Assembly of EPUs
A) Cdh5 Ubow mice were treated with tamoxifen, and their peripheral LN cells were analyzed 1 week later by flow cytometry (n = 4 mice).
(B) Predicted, non-mutually exclusive models of LN EC dynamics revealed by the Cdh5 Ubow mice.
In model 1, all labeled ECs divided and gave rise to small clusters of ECs sharing a similar color.
In model 2, a few ECs (*) massively divided to expand the vascular tree, forming large monocolored clusters of ECs.
In model 3, sprouting angiogenesis generated neo-vessels.
(C) Cdh5 Ubow mice were treated with tamoxifen and immunized 1 week later with CFA in the ears and rear footpads.
3 weeks later, total LN cells were labeled with DDAO-SE and injected i.v.
into mice for 10 min to label functional HEV cells.
LNs were sliced (200 mm thickness), clarified, and imaged by confocal microscopy.
Pictures show the appearance of contiguous and large monocolored segments of HEV cells only in inflamed LNs.
Inserts display high-magnification views of HEV cells.
Images are representative of four experiments (n = 3 mice per group).
Scale bars represent 300 mm.
See also Figure S1 and Movies S2, S3, and S4.

(D) All confocal datasets similar to those shown in (C) were processed for the generation of Voronoi tessellations (see Experimental Procedures) for quantifying clusters and computationally evaluating the significance of cluster formation by Monte Carlo simulations with the ClusterQuant software.

(E) The experimentally observed (original) cluster characteristics (numbers of CFP 2+ , YFP 2+ , and CFP + YFP + HEV cells per cluster) were compared to the results of the Monte Carlo simulations, in which the cells were randomly distributed (scrambled) on the basis of the observed microanatomy (displayed are 3 of 10,000 simulations).
Images are representative of four experiments (n = 3 mice).
***p < 10 À4 ; bars represent medians.
Figure 3. Expansion of the LN Vascular Tree Relies Exclusively on LN-Resident ECs(A) Ubc TOM mice were sub-lethally irradiated and reconstituted with the BM of Ubc GFP mice.
Chimeric mice were immunized with CFA in the ears and rear footpads and the EC fraction of their draining LNs was analyzed 3 weeks later by flow cytometry (n = 6 mice).
(B) Ubc TOM mice were surgically joined to WT mice for the creation of parabiotic pairs of mice sharing common blood circulation.
12 weeks later, the WT partner was immunized with CFA in the rear footpad.
The contribution of the Ubc TOM partner to the EC fraction of the draining LN of the WT partner was analyzed 3 weeks later by flow cytometry (n = 5 pairs of parabiotic mice).

Figure 4. HEV Cells Act as Progenitors of All LN Blood ECs (A) Representative pictures of monocolored capillary (arrows) and HEV (arrowheads) sprouts imaged in the inflamed LNs of Cdh5 Ubow mice as in Figure 2C.
Scale bar represents 50 mm.

(B) Monocolored capillary sprouts such as the ones displayed in (A) were identified on LN slices and used for determining the percentage of monocolored capillary sprouts connected to an HEV segment labeled with the same color.

(C) HEV cell and cBEC fractions were enriched from the peripheral LNs of tamoxifen-treated Cdh5 RFP mice and separately injected in the two inguinal LNs of the same WT mouse immunized 3 days earlier with CFA at the base of the tail.
Dot plots indicate the purity and viability of typical HEV cell and cBEC fractions isolated with this protocol.(legend
continued on next page)
Figure 5.
Return to LN Quiescence Relies on the Stochastic Death of Pre-existing and Neo-synthesized ECs (A) 2 3 10 6 plaque-forming units of VSV were injected in the ears and footpads of Apln TOM mice.
The day after, mice were treated with tamoxifen to label neo-synthesized ECs and their progeny.
Images are representative of clarified thick LN slices harvested at infection day 3 and stained for CD146 expression.
Abbreviations are as follows: S, sprout; and E, elongation.
Scale bar represents 50 mm.
(B) Draining LNs were photographed at day 7 (peak of the LN expansion) and day 60 (return to quiescence).
Images are representative of three experiments (n = 2 mice per group).

(C and D) Graphs indicate the corresponding total number of HEV cells (C) and percentages of Tomato + HEV cells (D) determined by flow cytometry from three independent experiments (n = 4 mice per group).
**p < 10 À2 ; ***p < 10 À3 ; ns, not significant.
Bars represent medians.
Empty squares represent VSV, and filled circles indicate controls.
(E) Representative images of clarified thick LN slices stained for T cell (CD3) and B cell (B220) markers reveal the localization of Tomato + neo-vessels in the inflamed LNs of VSV-infected mice.
Images are representative of three experiments (n = 2 mice per group).
Scale bars represent 200 mm.
I.M., A.J., C.S., S.W., and F.K. conducted the experiments and analyzed the data.
R.H.A. and B.Z. provided the Cdh5 CrERT2 and Apln Cre ERT2 mice.
S.A. provided VSV.
M.B. designed experiments, supervised the study, and wrote the paper.
We would like to thank Myriam Baratin and Rebecca Gentek for critical reading of the manuscript.

This study was funded by grants from the Agence National pour la Recherche (ANR-STROMA and ANR-10-INBS-04-01 France Bio Imaging) and the European Research Council under Horizon 2020 of the EU Framework Programme for Research and Innovation (647384-STROMA).
